body.name: The Thirteenth Child: A World War 2 historical novel based upon an enthralling and heart-wrenching true story

productInformation.name: Best Sellers Rank
productInformation.value: #16,818 in Kindle Store (See Top 100 in Kindle Store) #16 in World War I Historical Fiction (Books) #20 in Jewish Literature (Kindle Store) #86 in War Fiction (Kindle Store)

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2024
reviews.reviewText: So much went on in this book. I'll still give it 5 stars cause it kept my interest. I'm glad there will be a sequel cause the abrupt ending. Worth a read.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 5, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I could not put this book down and read it over 2 days. Having previously read of the truly horrific stories of those who were sadly held as prisoners in the camps, this book gives you a comprehensive understanding of what daily living experiences was like from when the German army rolled into Amsterdam. From living an ordinary family life to being transported like cattle to the camps. The storyline of the five family members is gripping, detailing how the Jewish community were slowly segregated. From having to wear stars on their clothing and unable to attend a cinema to being beaten in the street or homes raided in the middle of the night for being Jewish are just a few examples. This book also gives an accurate narrative of the Nazi invasion and how the regime was rolled out with violence and manipulation by army officials. The story of the Kisch family is heart-wrenching with the educational information that is threaded through the book is invaluable.This is a book that everyone should read as it gives an account of the impact that the war had on the Jewish community. It leaves you feeling very humbled hearing the stories of those trying to survive whilst remembering those who lost their lives.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 26, 2024
reviews.reviewText: A stunningly good first novel, based on Mark DeMeza’s shocking recent discovery of what happened to his family in wartime Amsterdam and their transportation to the Nazi death camps. The author skilfully interweaves a harrowing account of the fates of the fictional Kisch family with the historical events, places and main characters of the era (a compelling mix of the best and worst of humanity). As such, I found his novel both enthralling and highly educational. The narrative is also very well written, with numerous chapters that flow beautifully from Mark’s pen, whilst leaving the reader with a sense of foreboding about what is to follow or in deep shock at the dramatic and tragic events that unfold. Bravo to Mark - I very much look forward to the sequel.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 24, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I cannot recommend this book highly enough. If you enjoy historical fiction, or even if you are not sure, this book has everything. The story is based around a fictional Jewish family living through the occupation of Amsterdam. How their lives are affected in very different ways as they come to terms with the Nazi regime. Do they accept their situation or fight back.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 1, 2024
reviews.reviewText: From the moment I opened the book I was absolutely gripped. The way it is written is exceptional. It is just heartbreaking to comprehend how the cruelty of one human to another could ever be tolerated. Has really opened up my mind on what transpired during those day’s. Truly appalling. Totally recommend you read this book.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 5, 2024
reviews.reviewText: History was not my subject and I know only the bare bones of the Holocaust.This book being inspired by true events had my mind in a whirl. It didn't give horrific graphic details merely hinting at the atrocities leaving you free to fill in with your own imagination. Mine was very dark.The story had me constantly turning page after page and read it in just over two sittings. Well worth checking out.
